node.title: error while moving from mambaforge to  miniforge
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I was trying to pull the updates from 'moose/devel' branch. This also need to update the other libraries. Libraries got update without any error including those from 'moose-dev'. But while building the moose in 'opt' mode, I got the similar error as reported in  #26433 . i.e.,
error: 'class wasp::HITNodeView' has no member named 'token_type'; did you mean 'set_type'?
  687 |     auto token_type = value_node.token_type();
      |                                  ^~~~~~~~~~
      |                                  set_type

Then I tried to update 'WASP' by './scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh'. But got the same error while building moose. So, as suggested in #26433, I removed previous mambaforge all together and try to install miniforge as outlined here for Mac with intel processor.
But I am getting this error while executing conda init --all.
(base) subhenduchakraborty@pn2034990:~$ conda init --all
Password:
# >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ERROR REPORT <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/exceptions.py", line 1132, in __call__
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/cli/main.py", line 69, in main_subshell
        exit_code = do_call(args, p)
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/cli/conda_argparse.py", line 122, in do_call
        return getattr(module, func_name)(args, parser)
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/cli/main_init.py", line 33, in execute
        return initialize(context.conda_prefix, selected_shells, for_user, args.system,
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/core/initialize.py", line 113, in initialize
        run_plan_elevated(plan2)
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/core/initialize.py", line 709, in run_plan_elevated
        result = subprocess_call(
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/site-packages/conda/gateways/subprocess.py", line 98, in subprocess_call
        stdout, stderr = process.communicate(input=stdin)
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/subprocess.py", line 1154, in communicate
        stdout, stderr = self._communicate(input, endtime, timeout)
      File "/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/lib/python3.10/subprocess.py", line 2001, in _communicate
        input_view = memoryview(self._input)
    TypeError: memoryview: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'

`$ /Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/bin/conda init --all`

  environment variables:
                 CIO_TEST=<not set>
        CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV=base
                CONDA_EXE=/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/bin/conda
             CONDA_PREFIX=/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge
    CONDA_PROMPT_MODIFIER=(base)
         CONDA_PYTHON_EXE=/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/bin/python
               CONDA_ROOT=/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge
              CONDA_SHLVL=1
           CURL_CA_BUNDLE=<not set>
                FTP_PROXY=<set>
              HTTPS_PROXY=<set>
               HTTP_PROXY=<set>

                     PATH=/Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/bin:/Users/subhenduchakraborty/mi
                          niforge/condabin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/opt/X11
                          /bin
       REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=<not set>
            SSL_CERT_FILE=<not set>
                ftp_proxy=<set>
               http_proxy=<set>
              https_proxy=<set>

     active environment : base
    active env location : /Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge

       user config file : /Users/subhenduchakraborty/.condarc
 populated config files : /Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/.condarc

          conda version : 23.3.1

         python version : 3.10.12.final.0
       virtual packages : __archspec=1=x86_64
                          __osx=11.7.10=0
                          __unix=0=0
       base environment : /Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge  (writable)
      conda av data dir : /Users/subhenduchakraborty/miniforge/etc/conda

           channel URLs : https://conda.anaconda.org/conda-forge/osx-64

If submitted, this report will be used by core maintainers to improve
future releases of conda.

No report sent. To permanently opt-out, use

    $ conda config --set report_errors false

(base) subhenduchakraborty@pn2034990:~$

But despite that error, upon restarting the terminal, 'base' prompt did appear.
Any suggestion for way forward to initialize conda without that error?
Best
Subhendu

Update:
Even after that error, I can see search paths for libraries are set properly in the ~/.bash_profile by conda, so I continued with next steps. It compiled without any problem.

Hello
glad to hear it compiled. If you hit this error again you ll want to delete conda and re-install it. There is not usually a way to recover from these conda errors
Guillaume

node.title: Issues with Conda environment for MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Recently, I encountered some problems while installing gperftools for MOOSE code. This not only prevented me from using gperftools but also disrupted my Conda MOOSE environment. Now, when compiling my program, I am encountering the following error:
moose/framework/contrib/hit/parse.cc:687:34: error: 'class wasp::HITNodeView' has no member named 'token_type'; did you mean 'set_type'?
  687 |     auto token_type = value_node.token_type();
      |                                  ^~~~~~~~~~
      |                                  set_type

As a result, I plan to reinstall MOOSE, but Conda is having difficulties installing the MOOSE environment. Initially, during the installation of moose-tools, Conda would consume over 30GB of memory, leading to the forced termination of Conda by the system. After trying some suggestions found online, Conda is now throwing the following error during the installation of moose-dev and moose-tools:
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: unsuccessful initial attempt using frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.
Solving environment: unsuccessful attempt using repodata from current_repodata.json, retrying with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: unsuccessful initial attempt using frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.
Solving environment: | 
Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages.
This can take several minutes.  Press CTRL-C to abort.
failed                                                                                                                    

UnsatisfiableError: 

My Python version is 3.10.12.

Hello
I would delete conda and try again with our new miniforge install route
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
The first error was WASP out of sync. The last one is a conda problem and there's no other way around it that I know.
Guillaume

I successfully resolved the issue. Previously, in order to address some problems related to conda, I followed online advice and set the conda solver to "classic." After removing this command from the .condarc file, conda was able to install moose-dev successfully.
Thank you very much for your attention and advice.

node.title: Mamba error installing Perl for MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hello,
When attempting to follow the conda (mamba) installation instructions here I receive the following error:
error    libmamba Error opening for reading "/cluster/VAST/rulisp-lab/cpg/mamba/pkgs/perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5/info/index.json": No such file or directory
perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5.conda extraction failed
Found incorrect download: perl. Aborting
I also retrieved the specific conda file and attempted a direct installation of Perl as:
(moose) [rulisp@hellbender:temp]$ mamba install linux-64_perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5.conda
Downloading and Extracting Packages
didn't find info-linux-64_perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5 component in /cluster/VAST/rulisp-lab/cpg/mamba/pkgs/linux-64_perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5.conda
LookupError("didn't find info-linux-64_perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5 component in /cluster/VAST/rulisp-lab/cpg/mamba/pkgs/linux-64_perl-5.32.1-4_hd590300_perl5.conda")
Any suggestion would be much appreciated.
Thank you,

Hello
Looks like a bad package. If it s not recovering by itself, and removing the package is not enough, do you have the option to uninstall conda and try again from scratch?
Guillaume

Hello,

Unfortunately, I don't have install (root) privileges for the system so I'm mostly stuck with the versions of conda and mamba that the administrators provide.

Is there a way to install a different version of Perl that will still be compatible with MOOSE, but which doesn't have the missing info?

Yeah there are a few options then.

follow the linux install, which you can do yourself with your own conda, not the system one. But the performance will be much lower notably because MPI is not compiled for your HPC system
follow the HPC system install, which you should also be able to do yourself, but if there are missing libraries / modules you may want to ask your HPC team to install those at the cluster level
get your HPC folks to install MOOSE for you and make it available as a module if that's what's used on that system

If you follow the 3rd root, they probably would install the combined executable in moose/modules.
If you want to add new objects (coding new ones) you ll need to use dynamic loading to load them

Thank you very much for the guidance. I'll probably see if the HPC administrators can do the install for me so I can load it as a module.

node.title: Computing residual using an input vector
node.bodyText:
Hello and Happy New Year!
In MOOSE, I am generating a new solution vector for temperature for a heat conduction problem using a predictor. The predictor takes in the initial guess at the beginning of each time step then predicts a new solution and uses that as the initial guess.
To see if my predictor is working well, I would ideally like to calculate the residual using both the original initial guess for the timestep, along with my new vector, so I would be calculating the residual using two different vectors.
My question is if there is any functionality in MOOSE that already exists to do this, or would I have to take an approach similar to that in ArrayDiffsusion.C (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/variables/ArrayMooseVariable.html) where they wrote in the governing equation and solved there.
That would be fine to do, but I was just wondering if you all had an internal method to do this already made or if there was another good example to look at for how to do this.
Thanks you!
Charlie
@lindsayad @grmnptr @oanaoana either of you used an API that does this before?
Look for FEProblemBase::computeResidual and NonlinearSystemBase::computeResidual functions in the doxygen. Most of them take in a solution vector which is used to evaluate the residual at.

The error message is giving you a clue. You cannot use a reference for the residual_org vector because you are not initializing it. Either initialize it or create it by value instead of a reference (just delete the &)

node.title: Problem in Creating Application on HCP Cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I encountered an issue while creating an application on the ComputeCanada HCP cluster. Following the installation of MOOSE on the cluster, including PETSc, libMesh, and WASP components, I successfully built and tested MOOSE as per the provided instructions. The tests concluded with 3839 passed, 367 skipped, 0 pending, and 0 failed. Subsequently, I proceeded to create an application named "precipitation" (refer to the attached picture). After initial successful make and test operations, I modified the MakeFile, changing "All Module" to "Yes." However, this adjustment did not yield the expected results. It seems that only one test was rechecked instead of the anticipated comprehensive check of multiple tests.
I suspect there might be an issue with the testing process or the MakeFile configuration. Could you kindly provide insights into what might be causing this discrepancy and guide me on resolving the problem?
Many thanks in advance for your kind support,
Sajjad
PS: I tested both make -j 6 and make -j 1 while creating and testing, and the results were same.

Hello
When you create a new application it comes preloaded with only a single test as an example.
If you want to you can pass arguments to run_tests (see --help) to run the moose framework or modules tests with your application but it s not necessary.
Guillaume

node.title: Some questions about two-phase flow and RELAP7
node.bodyText:
Hi @GiudGiud and @joshuahansel,
These days I would like to develop a two-phase six-equation model using MOOSE, which seems easier than the seven-equation model that was used in RELAP7. Which of these two models is more suitable or easier to develop in MOOSE?
By the way, I would like to know if the RELAP7 can calculate some accident conditions, like LOCA, RIA, LOFA..... Because I can not find any reference about this. If yes, could you please kindly show me some references?
Best regards.
@licharlot will know which tech reports have accidental transients with RELAP7

To my knowledge, I don't think either model is easier to develop than the other. RELAP-7 is capable of simulating accident conditions like the ones you listed. The only question is whether it will be robust enough to finish your transient through any phase disappearance (zero volume fraction). As far as why RELAP5 has been more successful in this area (I'm assuming this is the case anyway), I don't think it's necessarily 6-equation vs. 7-equation - I think it's just a better phase disappearance treatment. I think that both 6-equation and 7-equation models must treat phase disappearance in some way. I would say it may be not just a function of the flow model but also of the fluid property calculations robustness.
As for references, I would just see what comes up when you google "RELAP-7". I don't know that it's worth the effort of reading everything - just know that some accidents may succeed and some may fail due to phase disappearance robustness issues - it all depends on your problem.

Thanks for you reply! Thank you very much. By the way, I also have other questions (I developed the six-equation model):

what the variables of six-equation model should be? [α, p, ul, ug, Tl, Tg] or [(αρ)l, (αρ)g, (αρu)l, (αρu)g, (αρE)l, (αρE)g]? I know the former form is for incompressiable flow, and the later is for compressiable flow. Two-phase flow sometime is incompressiable(α=0), but sometimes it is compressiable(α=1). Which one should I choose?
If α=0 or α=1, the 6-equation would become to 3-equation, which could cause non-convergence for NAN. Now, I just constrain the αmin = 1.0e-4 and αmax = 0.9999 to always use 6-equation. Is it correct?
which fluid properties does RELAP7 use? Water97FluidProperty? Now, I use IAPWS-IF97. But it is a problem when it is single-phase. For example, when it is liquid (α <= αmin), should the vapour properties be liquid? If yes, the properties will change rapidly causing divergence. Now, I also constrain the properties using the variable p and Tsat+0.0001 to make sure they are always vapour properties.
For the convection terms in 6-equation, I use roe-type numerical scheme and DG kernel, just like THM. But it just calculate convection term. The momentum equations of six-equation model have the terms in red circle. How to solve this term? Now, I just put it in Material using (αi+1 - αi)/xi+1 - xi. Is it correct? Is there any better way?


Thank you very much! I'm so sorry I have so many questions.....

The variables can be either of those sets. We chose the latter set for the 7-equation model, but I've been wondering if we should additionally implement the former. In terms of the formulation, it does not matter, but I do believe it may have an impact on the numerics, perhaps the conditioning of your Jacobian dF/dU. You say alpha=0 and alpha=1 are related to compressibility? I don't understand that - it just determines which phase is present.
You can try that strategy. We certainly have, and it was not a silver bullet. Maybe it'll work out for you.
Typically we used the 1995 water formulation in RELAP-7. We could use the 1997 formulation if all of the necessary interfaces were implemented. And your questions indicate the tricky question - what happens to the vanished phase? A good question that we don't quite have the answer to. We have some relaxation terms that would keep that phase around saturation conditions of the other phase. That may work.
The 7-equation model has similar terms but uses the interfacial pressure instead. That term becomes a non-conservative contribution to our inter-cell flux vector, so it is treated in a similar manner as the advective terms. Otherwise you could try it as a volumetric term if you're able to produce some approximation like you've suggested within the cell volume.

In general, and I cannot speak for everyone on the MOOSE team, but we don't have all of the answers to the questions of what's best for a two-phase flow formulation. We only know what we attempted, and we did not have the time and funding to produce a formulation that was entirely satisfactory, so I'd suggest you do some research into the methodology from a literature review. What we can definitely help you with is the implementation in MOOSE. The rest of the help we give you may be questionable.
Tagging @joe61vette who has quite a bit of experience with phase disappearance and attempts to model it with MOOSE (mostly unsuccessful I fear)

Just a note that the navier_stokes module has both incompressible and compressible formulations for single phase flow. I think that in the future if/when we add an incompressible formulation in the thermal_hydraulics module, we will leverage a lot of what we have in navier_stokes

hi @joshuahansel,
Thanks for your detailed reply.

what I said α is αg. αg = 0 means it is liquid, since the mass, momentum and energy equation on the left side is equal to 0 for vapour phase. In this case, it is incompressible. On the other hand, if αg = 1, it is pure vapour, which means it is compressible. As you said, the formulation has impact on the numerics, so which formulation is better for the two-phase six-equation model?
Could you please kindly tell me the strategy you used? or could you give me some reference? I think my strategy is not very good.
For the properties, I noticed RELAP7 also has the stiffened gas equation of state (SGEOS). Does it work? Although SGEOS is not accurate enough, I think it does not have the same problem, like IF-97.
when you treat this term, do you use the numerical scheme, like HLLC or something else? Additionally, If we treat this term in the similar manner, it is necessary to implement an additional boundary condition, what the boundary flux should be? (flux_advective + p*flux_alpha) * _normal * _test[_i][_qp]?

Thank you very much. These issues will not be encountered unless we are truly writing these codes. So it is hard for me to find these answers in literature. It needs the experiences that develop two-phase flow, which is exactly lacking for me. Your suggestion is really useful for me. Thank you again.

Ok
Essentially this was the strategy we used, but we may have done it in a different way. We used a "remapper" such that the actual solution could go out of the range (0,1), but it would be uniquely mapped to numbers within (0,1). Yes, it keeps volume fraction in the range, but there are other issues.
SGEOS works and is much more robust than other options, but even it is not immune to phase disappearance issues.
Yes, you would have a corresponding flux on the boundary.

The best reference for details would be the RELAP-7 theory manual, which you can find by googling.
OK, thanks for your patience！

Hi @joshuahansel,
Could you please tell me the numerical method that RELAP7 used to deal with the p*∂α_g/∂x term? I searched through the RELAP7 theory manual, but I could not find it. Does it use the centered average of the left and right side fluxes (first-order)?

The p*dalpha/dx term was transformed into d(p*alpha)/dx - alpha*dp/dx. See the 2-phase flow spatial discretization section in the RELAP-7 theory manual (5.2.3 for me). The p*alpha in d(p*alpha)/dx is added to the conservative numerical flux, and the non-conservative term alpha*dp/dx term is integrated approximating alpha constant over the element.

Can you perform the following commands and report the results:
mamba activate moose
cd ~/projects/moose
scripts/versioner.py wasp --yaml | grep install
mamba list | grep moose
I want to see what version of wasp your version of MOOSE requires... and what you have currently installed.

All right, my friend. The result is
(base) sjtu@sjtu:~/Desktop$ mamba activate moose
(moose) sjtu@sjtu:~/Desktop$ cd ~/projects/moose
(moose) sjtu@sjtu:~/projects/moose$ scripts/versioner.py wasp --yaml | grep install
  install: moose-wasp=2023.05.01=build_0
(moose) sjtu@sjtu:~/projects/moose$ mamba list | grep moose
# packages in environment at /home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose:
moose-dev                 2023.10.06              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh             2023.09.06              build_3    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.2.6                   build_4    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.2                  build_11    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-peacock             2023.09.15           h934c01f_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.19.3.884.g08c1f94318e         build_1    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-test-tools          2023.08.31      py310h0c21752_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2023.08.31      py310hfccbfe0_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-wasp                2023.10.06              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
(moose) sjtu@sjtu:~/projects/moose$

Looks like you have a very updated set of Conda packages, but your version of MOOSE is fairly old. Can you update your version of MOOSE? Or are you busy working on a specific checkout?
If you need to downgrade the Conda environment I can help with that...
So what do you mean? Have you mentioned the two ways: downgrade the Conda environment or upgrade the version of MOOSE. Which one should I choose?
And I edited the discussion to tell you the full story of what happened

We would prefer you stay as up-to-date as possible :)
In that case:
cd ~/projects/moose
git fetch origin
git pull
should bring you in-line with what you have for your Conda environment. Afterwards, you'll want to clean out the failed previous build, and start anew:
cd ~/projects/moese
git clean -xfd     # save any uncommitted work. 
                   # But it sounds like you won't have any
cd test
make -j 6
FYI, the Conda packages and your MOOSE repository hold a very tight bond on where they need to be. Basically, when you update one, you should update the other... What I mean by that, is when ever you:
mamba update --all   # or mamba update moose-dev
you should also:
git fetch origin
git pull
and vice versa.
I just read your updated post. Ahh yeah... You basically performed a clean reinstall, which will grab the latest available Conda packages.

Then I try to do the run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh, it cannot work, either

I think this is happening because you were operating in the (base) environment:
mamba activate moose
and then try!
But also, you should not need to build PETSc, libMesh, or wasp (using those update_and_rebuild_ scripts). You have these packages already installed via Conda.

node.title: Handling Mesh Mapping for Faces Between Different Meshes in MOOSE
node.bodyText: I've learned about the existence of CoarseMeshExtraElementIDGenerator in MOOSE, which seems to be designed for mapping between meshes in different layers. However, it appears that it only stores the mapping between cells using ExtraElementID. I'm wondering if MOOSE provides a method to handle mapping between faces of different meshes. Is there a functionality or another class that can be used for this purpose? Any guidance or information on this matter would be greatly appreciated.

Hello
We dont have anything out of the box. However you could:

redevelop the CoarseMeshExtra....IDGenerator with Nodal extra IDs instead of element IDs. Then the nodes are on faces and you can work with that
OR
from the fine face, you can get the fine element near the face, then the coarse element near the face using the ID, then from there you could find the coarse element face itself. It's a little convoluted but this is not going to be very expensive to do.

Once you have created the mapping, you can cache it if you care about performance
Guillaume
I get it, thank you for your response.

node.title: StiffenedGasTwoPhaseFluidProperties problem
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I would like to use StiffenedGasTwoPhaseFluidProperties to calculate the material properties of two-phase flow.
I defined fp like this:
in .h file:
  const TwoPhaseFluidProperties & _fp;
  const SinglePhaseFluidProperties & _fp_liquid;
  const SinglePhaseFluidProperties & _fp_vapor;

in .C file:
  _fp(getUserObject<TwoPhaseFluidProperties>("fp")),
  _fp_liquid(getUserObject<SinglePhaseFluidProperties>(_fp.getLiquidName())),
  _fp_vapor(getUserObject<SinglePhaseFluidProperties>(_fp.getVaporName()))

and 

  _rho_liq[_qp] = _fp_liquid.rho_from_p_T(1.5e6,400.0);
  _rho_vap[_qp] = _fp_vapor.rho_from_p_T(1.8e6,300.0);


in the input file:
[FluidProperties]
  [./two_phase]
    type = StiffenedGasTwoPhaseFluidProperties
  [../]

And then some error occurred:

Is there something wrong?
Thanks!

Hello
getUserObject takes the parameter name not the object name.
getUserObjectByName, if it exists, would take the object name like you have now "_fp.getLiquidName()"
Guillaume
Thanks a lot, it works!

node.title: A phase field model with inelastic stress update.
node.bodyText:
I am very new to MOOSE. I would like to learn to apply the inelastic stress update in a phase field model, and I try to use base_name to implement this. However, the following input file does not work well, which could not converges even though I have scaled the converge criteria. So, I feel lost about how to use the inelastic strain in phase field models. It is my pleasure to hear some suggestions about it from everyone. Thanks!
#
# Example 2
# Phase change driven by a mechanical (elastic) driving force.
# An oversized phase inclusion grows under a uniaxial tensile stress.
# Check the file below for comments and suggestions for parameter modifications.
#

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 10
  ny = 10
  nz = 0
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 50
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 50
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 0
  elem_type = QUAD4
  uniform_refine = 3
[]

[Variables]
  [./eta]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    [./InitialCondition]
      type = RandomIC
      min = 0
      max = 0.1
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    strain = FINITE
    incremental = true
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy'
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./eta_bulk]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = eta
    f_name = F
  [../]
  [./eta_interface]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta
    kappa_name = kappa_eta
  [../]
  [./time]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta
  [../]
[]

#
# Try visualizing the stress tensor components as done in Conserved.i
#

[Materials]
  [./consts]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    block = 0
    prop_names  = 'L kappa_eta'
    prop_values = '1  1e3'
  [../]

  # matrix phase
  [./stiffness_a]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    base_name = phasea
    block = 0
    youngs_modulus = 1
    poissons_ratio = 0.25
  [../]
  [./strain_a]
    type =  ComputePlaneFiniteStrain
    block = 0
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phasea
  [../]
  [./stress_a]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'isoplas'
    block = 0
    base_name = phasea
  [../]
  [./isoplas]
    type = IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
    yield_stress = 5e-3
    hardening_constant = 0.0
    relative_tolerance = 1e-20
    absolute_tolerance = 1e-8
    max_inelastic_increment = 0.000001
  [../]
  [./elastic_free_energy_a]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phasea
    f_name = Fea
    block = 0
    args = ''
  [../]

  # oversized precipitate phase (simulated using thermal expansion)
  [./stiffness_b]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    base_name = phaseb
    block = 0
    youngs_modulus = 1
    poissons_ratio = 0
  [../]
  [./strain_b]
    type = ComputePlaneFiniteStrain
    block = 0
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phaseb
  [../]
  [./stress_b]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'creep'
    block = 0
    base_name = phaseb
  [../]
  [./creep]
    type = PowerLawCreepStressUpdate
    block = 0
    coefficient = 0.5e-14
    n_exponent = 1
    m_exponent = -0.5
    activation_energy = 0
  [../]
  [./elastic_free_energy_b]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phaseb
    f_name = Feb
    block = 0
    args = ''
  [../]

  # Generate the global free energy from the phase free energies
  [./switching]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
    block = 0
    eta = eta
    h_order = SIMPLE
  [../]
  [./barrier]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
    block = 0
    eta = eta
    g_order = SIMPLE
  [../]
  [./free_energy]
    type = DerivativeTwoPhaseMaterial
    block = 0
    f_name = F
    fa_name = Fea
    fb_name = Feb
    eta = eta
    args = ''
    W = 1
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]

  # Generate the global stress from the phase stresses
  [./global_stress]
    type = TwoPhaseStressMaterial
    block = 0
    base_A = phasea
    base_B = phaseb
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./bottom_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./top_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'top'
    value = 5
  [../]
  [./bottom_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0
  [../]

[]

[Preconditioning]
  # active = ' '
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = bdf2

  # this gives best performance on 4 cores
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type  -sub_pc_type '
  petsc_options_value = 'asm       lu'

  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 10
  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-10
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 10

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = SolutionTimeAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.1
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
What units is the mesh in? Clearly not SI with a yield stress of 5e-3.
And is the yield stress consistent with those units?
Guillaume

Thank you for sharing your concerns. The unit is not SI, and I might misuse parameters. In this model, I divide the mechanical quantity by $\Delta f$(about 10E9) and this might result in the yield stress is not consistent with others. I will check the consistency of units, whilst I have tried a few different parameter combinations, and they did not work. So, I worried about whether my idea is right. Do you have any advice or examples about applying inelastic deformation into phase field models? Thank you very much.

Hello, I get an error like
Cannot take square root of a number less than or equal to zero in the calculation of 
C3_test for the Rashid approximation for the rotation tensor. This zero or negative number 
may occur when elements become heavily distorted.

And I find the mesh definitely is wrong. Do you have any comments on this? I have no idea about what is wrong with the equilibrium equation. Thank you for sharing.
Yuntong

Hello mooser,
After carefully checking, I found that the deformation is too large and the time unite is not consistent with other parameters. I corrected those problems and the computation can be done rightly. Thanks.
